summary: This is an email chain between Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorneys and a federal prosecutor regarding logistical arrangements for the defense team to review physical and electronic evidence in the criminal case. The correspondence details disputes over access to evidence, particularly 'highly confidential' nude images and videos seized from Jeffrey Epstein's devices, and the conditions under which Maxwell and her attorneys can inspect materials held by the FBI.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Partner at Haddon, Morgan & Foreman, P.C. who is the primary defense counsel corresponding with the prosecution to arrange evidence review for Maxwell's defense. She outlines the defense's requirements and challenges the prosecution's proposed conditions.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: Defense attorney cc'd on the correspondence regarding evidence review arrangements.

persons.name: Christian R Everdell
persons.context: Attorney from Cohen & Gresser LLP who is part of Maxwell's defense team and is cc'd on the evidence review correspondence.

persons.name: Bobbi C Sternheim
persons.context: Defense attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell who is cc'd on all correspondence regarding the evidence review logistics.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The accused in the criminal case US v. Maxwell (20 Cr. 330). Her defense team is seeking to arrange for her to review discovery materials, including highly confidential images, to assist in her defense.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned as the source from whose electronic devices and residences the 'highly confidential' nude/partially nude images and videos were seized by the FBI.

connections.description: Menninger is a defense attorney representing Maxwell in the criminal case, as evidenced by her correspondence to secure evidence review for Maxwell's defense.
Pagliuca is a defense attorney on Maxwell's legal team, cc'd on all strategic correspondence about evidence review.
Everdell is a defense attorney from Cohen & Gresser LLP on Maxwell's legal team, involved in evidence review discussions.
Sternheim is a defense attorney for Maxwell, included in all email correspondence regarding evidence access.
The evidence being reviewed, including images seized from Epstein's devices, is part of the case against Maxwell, implying their alleged association in criminal activity.

events.title: Scheduled Physical Evidence Review
events.description: The defense team proposes the week of April 12 for reviewing all physical evidence from the FBI Bronx warehouse at 500 Pearl Street, with Ghislaine Maxwell present.

events.title: Scheduled Electronic Evidence Review
events.description: The defense proposes that during the week of April 19, Maxwell be produced to 500 Pearl Street to review all 5,507 'highly confidential' electronic images and videos on a provided laptop.

events.title: FBI Searches of Epstein Residences
events.description: The FBI's New York Office conducted searches of Jeffrey Epstein's residences in New York and the U.S. Virgin Islands, seizing physical items and electronic media (discs with images).

events.title: Discovery Production
events.description: The prosecution produced discovery to the defense, including an index of physical items from the FBI-Miami office's investigation and scans of numerous items.

events.title: Previous Evidence Review at MDC
events.description: The defense client (Maxwell) and counsel previously reviewed some 'highly confidential' images at the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC) in November.

locations: 500 Pearl Street, New York, NY (likely a federal courthouse or government building)
Epstein's residences in the U.S. Virgin Islands
1 St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007 (Southern District of New York USAO)
keyFacts: The defense is seeking to review over 5,500 'highly confidential' electronic images and videos seized from Jeffrey Epstein's devices, categorized as: ~2,100 never-before-produced images from Epstein's devices, ~3,400 previously reviewed images from discs seized in 2019, and ~7 hard-copy nude images from the FBI Florida investigation.

A significant point of contention is the FBI's restriction that only a single, clean government laptop can be used to review the 'highly confidential' obscene material, which the defense argues impedes Maxwell's ability to meaningfully participate in her defense.

The physical evidence is primarily stored at an FBI warehouse in the Bronx, with conditions that prohibit defense attorneys from bringing laptops or internet-connected devices into the warehouse, allowing only a disconnected digital camera for photography.

The correspondence reveals the massive scale of evidence in the case, including 'bulky' items like massage tables, and indicates the FBI took several weeks to review all the images on the discs seized from Epstein's residences.
The defense alleges that the FBI did not prepare an inventory of evidence when it was seized from New York and the U.S. Virgin Islands, complicating the review process.
